-2-
Xi had been commandeered to carry troops to the Red front to the
north over which we had just flown.
The city was astir with much
activity.
Kweiyang soldiers remaining behind are
boys of fifteen
or sixteen in wretched ill-fitting tattered uniforms.
Their cartridge belts
empty and
only as a handle for the rusty bayonet at the end.
their guns old and probably useful
The difficulty
of relying on such troops is that
they will gladly join the enemy
if given half a chance.
Their brothers among the bandits or Reds
have lots of apportunities for big money through looting the shops
and houses in the cities which are
In contrast to such
privileges the loyal troops get $3.00 per month when they get paia
It was very amusing at dinner tonight.
Our party consist-
ed of Mr.
and Mrs. Robinson and Mr. and Mrs.
Butler who occupy this
mission house.
Mr. Robinson about 40 - well built - talkative.
Butler - God fearing type - about 35 - firm,
efficient determined.
Mrs. Butler around 30, rather attractive and quite feminine - looks
like she would love to buy some fine lingerie if hubby would sanction
the purchase - which he very clearly would not.
Mrs. Robinson looks
older than her husband - a firm determined face - straight mouth
turning down slightly at the corners - overcome completely by
her will,
hostility and righteous indignation.
smoking which bothered her.
We compromised with the missionaries
by not taking a drink and they in turn waived objections verbally
at least,
our smoking.
The guests were Tommy Taylor, pilot
Chiang Kai-shek's Curtiss Condor and his mechanic Gay, a drawling
They had nearly
cracked up
the day before trying to stagger
off the small field at
Chungking with a heavily overloaded plane
The ship hit a klut pile of rocks at
and luckily finaly careened crazily away just escaping a very bad
They had been working all
day repairing the damaged tail
surfaces of the plane and fixing an emergency tail skid out of scrap
iron and a short section of a log.
We feared profanity but the boys
kept conversation under
Harry Smith,
spent so much time with missionaries during the last
three years
of his meanderings
around China with Chiang that he is perfectly at
home with them.
Pilot Nelson of our ship and I completed the party.
The others in our party Ki Chun, Nieh and co-pilot Wong stayed with
the French Fathers who years ago converted Nieh to the
Catholic
The conversion was not 100% successful I fear because
Nieh's wife and number one concubine always come out to the airport
together to meet him when he returns from a trip.
A hint has come to us through Mr. Butler that our
or Chungking if weather is more favorable in that direction.
turn in now.
Wednesday - April 3rd. (Flying down the Yangsze from
Hankow to Shanghai).
On Monday April
first at Kweiyang we learned
that martial law would be declared and the city
gates closed at
We could get no transportation to the field but Harry Smith,
Taylor and Gay had a Ford roadster assigned to them and we were told
that if we started walking we could get out of town before the gates
closed and could intercept Harry's car on its way back to town.
we hired a coolie to carry our baggage and after some arguments with
soldiers got outside the
commandeered for the militar:
passing several
barricades of rocks and sand bags with machine
